intro: Meconopsis psilonomma var. zhaganaensis, commonly known as the Zhagana meconopsis, is a perennial herb native to the high-altitude regions of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its striking blue to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky and alpine environments, thriving in cool, moist conditions. Its leaves are lanceolate and arranged alternately along the stem, while its flowers are solitary and borne on short pedicels. This variant is notable for its ornamental value and is often cultivated in botanical gardens for its beauty and ecological significance.
